conclusion: A smooth, light, inextensible rope of length R is tied to a small ball of mass m that can slide without friction on a fixed, vertical, circular guide of radius R.
The rope passes through a smooth hole drilled at the topmost point of the guide, so that the portion of the rope outside the guide (above the hole) can be pulled with a force F.
Initially the rope makes an acute angle θ₀ with the vertical and the ball is at rest.
The question asks: while the rope makes a (general) angle θ with the vertical, what pulling force F must be applied?
Take the ring’s centre O as the origin of gravitational potential energy. Let the vertical through O be the y-axis, positive upward.

Because the rope passes through the top of the ring, the part of the rope between the hole and the ball is always tangent to the ring at the hole. Hence inside the ring the rope segment has fixed length R (the ring’s radius). The angle between the rope and the vertical is θ at an arbitrary instant.
Horizontal distance of the ball from the vertical diameter: x = R sin θ
Vertical distance of the ball above O: y = R cos θ − R
No friction acts on the ball; the rope is light; the only external work on the inside portion (ball + interior segment of rope) is done by the tension at the hole.

Call the tension in the rope T(θ). If the rope is pulled quasi-statically—that is, the outside segment moves so slowly that the kinetic energy of the ball remains negligible—then the total mechanical energy of the inside system remains zero at every instant.
T(θ)⋅(small displacement through the hole) = increase in gravitational potential energy of the ball.
Differential work equation T·ds = m g dy where ds is the rope withdrawn through the hole while the ball’s vertical coordinate changes by dy.
By geometry the withdrawn length ds equals the decrease in the straight-line segment from the hole to the ball: ds = −d(R cos θ) = R sin θ·dθ.
Also dy = d(R cos θ − R) = −R sin θ·dθ.
T(θ)(R sin θ·dθ) = m g(−R sin θ·dθ) ⇒ T(θ) = −m g
Magnitude of the tension in the inside segment: T(θ) = m g
The rope is light, passes over a smooth hole (no friction), and only changes direction; therefore the magnitudes of its tensions are equal on both sides of the hole: F = T(θ) = m g.
